bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 6, 1930

div1.p: Carter requests copies of the bibliography and library cards used for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and thanks Frost for the generous acknowledgement of Brown's outstanding work in the preface of the book.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 6, 1930
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
October 6, 1930.
Dr. Wade R. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Your letter of October 4th., with enclosures, has just
reached me. I had written you the same day, after receiving
Susan's long distance telephone message, a most inadequate
expression of “thanksgiving” for the news that the MS of
The Early History of Yellow Fever was on its way to New York.
This letter, delayed in the sending, should reach you at about the
same time as this note.

I shall not try to-night to answer your letter in detail.
I am, however, sending this note by special delivery to ask that,
if it be possible, you let Miss Brown and myself have the whole
copied bibliography along with the library cards by next Saturday.
This, you already state, you will endeavor to have done within this week.
I am, however, stressing it, because Miss Brown only has two free
Sundays a month and next Sunday is one of them. Saturday night, and
Sunday then would be our best chance for uninterrupted work to-
gether without her taking some of her few remaining days of annual
leave. This, however, she will do if necessary. I am glad that
you revised the acknowledgement to Miss Brown on page v of the Pre-
face. She considers your revised form far beyond her deserts, but
greatly appreciates it as an expression of your opinion. For my-
self, I am “pen-bound” where you both are concerned. Her work and
devotion to the book bibliography are as beyond adequate praise by me as
is your own. I think that it would be hard to better your acknowledge-
ment to Miss Brown in the necessarily brief space alloted for such
purposes in the Preface.
With grateful remembrances from both Miss Brown and myself.
